question.title: How to use scroll bars in Java FX/How to render a portion of a container based on scroll bar?
question.body:
I am trying to develop an application using JavaFX. I am currently trying to make a dynamically scaling table with a variable number of rows and columns, and a header that stays in place vertically. To achieve this, I opted to use two scroll bars instead of a scrollPane, as I am not aware of a way create a header that only scrolls with one scroll bar using scroll pane. I have the header (which should only scroll horizontally) in a separate container from the body. All of this is part of a larger scene.

I used the valueProperty listener as shown here. I was expecting that the containers would extend past what was initially rendered, allowing each label to be fully readable if you scroll. However, the containers' do not move with scroll bar, even when the layout value changes. Furthermore, some of the labels that make up the table do not display all of their text. How do I achieve what I was intending while having both containers scroll horizontally and only one scroll vertically?

Below is a sample of my code.

@FXML
HBox hBoxHeader;

@FXML
ScrollBar sbVertical;

@FXML
ScrollBar sbHorizontal;

public void initialize() {
        sbHorizontal.setMax(10);
        sbHorizontal.valueProperty().addListener(new ChangeListener<Number>() {
            @Override
            public void changed(ObservableValue<? extends Number> observableValue, Number oldVal, Number newVal) {
                hBoxHeader.setLayoutX(-newVal.doubleValue());
                vBoxListIncomes.setLayoutX(-newVal.doubleValue());
            }
        });

        sbVertical.valueProperty().addListener(new ChangeListener<Number>() {
            @Override
            public void changed(ObservableValue<? extends Number> observableValue, Number oldVal, Number newVal) {
                vBoxListIncomes.setLayoutY(-newVal.doubleValue());
            }
        });
    }

question_comments.body: "I think there should be a way to do what I was trying to do" -> Probably there is a way, but I don't understand your exact requirements well enough to explain. Even if I did understand, the answer could be complex. If your requirements are mainly the same as for a TableView, it would not be worthwhile (for you or me) to recreate most of the functionality of the existing control.

@fawfulsPikminArmy TableView has built-in scrolling, including scroll bars. It's also "virtualized", which means it will only create and display enough cells to fill the viewport and reuse cells as the table is scrolled. The benefit of that is it can "display" thousands or millions of items without impacting rendering performance.
TableView always contains scrollbars.  It is intended for exactly this kind of situation.

uh... I didn't know it existed. Will it work with scroll bars? I may need to rework large portions of the project. Thank you. (I'm gonna leave the question open since I think there should be a way to do what I was trying to do.)
This seems like a use case for TableView. Is there a reason you can't use that control?
